definition: Neuroendocrine circuit for stress: CRH (hypothalamus) → ACTH (anterior pituitary) → cortisol (adrenal cortex) with negative feedback on both hypothalamus and pituitary.
why_it_matters: Explains patterns in cortisol testing, responses to stress, and the physiology behind Cushing syndromes and adrenal insufficiency.
how_youll_see_it: Early‑morning (8am) cortisol vs late‑night salivary cortisol
Interpretation of ACTH values (high vs low) to localize pathology
problem_solving: Think in feedback loops: what is producing cortisol and who is driving it?
High cortisol + low ACTH → adrenal source or exogenous glucocorticoids
High cortisol + high ACTH → pituitary (Cushing disease) vs ectopic; use high‑dose dex or IPSS
tricks: Random afternoon cortisol is rarely useful—use standardized morning/late‑night tests
Chronic exogenous steroids suppress CRH/ACTH → adrenal atrophy → crisis risk
exam_appearance: CRH stimulates ACTH from anterior pituitary; cortisol provides negative feedback
High‑dose dex suppresses pituitary ACTH more than ectopic sources
treatment: HPA axis itself isn’t a disease—treat the underlying disorder (Cushing, Addison, exogenous steroids)
Stress‑dose steroids when physiologically suppressed axes are stressed (eg, surgery, sepsis)
red_flags: Adrenal crisis: hypotension, hyponatremia, vomiting—give IV hydrocortisone immediately
algorithm: Suspected hypercortisolism → screening test (overnight dex OR late‑night salivary OR 24‑hr urine)
High ACTH → pituitary vs ectopic (high‑dose dex ± IPSS); Low ACTH → adrenal imaging
Suspected adrenal insufficiency → 8am cortisol ± ACTH stimulation

cases.stem: A 45‑year‑old with central obesity and violaceous striae.
cases.teaching: Pituitary corticotrophs retain some feedback responsiveness.

cases.stem: A 67‑year‑old with chronic prednisone abruptly stopped before elective surgery.
cases.teaching: Exogenous steroids suppress the HPA axis; always taper and consider stress doses.
